content.description: Excellent handcrack that starts with a few easy horizontal moves, then drop in bomber hands as it turns vertical to the top.
content.protection: Pad. Hosts a flat dirt landing - so often done without, but a slip from the top wouldn't be nice.
content.location: Very obvious handcrack right of the trail, just a few dozen yards before cutting up to the Girlie Man wall.

content.description:
Start at the base of Sassy. Begin by ascending the crack but then cross left onto the face, aiming for an obvious bolt, and continue climbing left of the arete.  Follow bolts straight up through a few thin friction moves (between first and second bolt) to easier ground.

If anyone has a route name and FA let me know.
content.protection: 3 bolts and a two bolt anchor.  Hand sized gear if you want to place protection in the crack before reaching the first bolt.   BE ADVISED: The anchors are widely spaced.  Use a cordalette.
content.location: Look for the large crack splitting the East face of the girlie man wall. This crack is Sassy.

content.description: This is a right arching finger crack. Start in the crack climb it to its end then continue up face and slightly left to a two bolt anchor.
content.protection: A single set of Cams or stoppers up to 0.75" works well.
content.location: After arriving at the base of the large slab scramble up and right of face to base of Girlie Man. The crack is 5 feet to the right of Girlie Man.

content.description: This is a three bolt face climb located around the corner slightly up hill to the the left of Dog Gone It. Start is at base on the left of rounded and low angle face. Crux is friction intensive just below second bolt. The belayer should pay close attention as a ground fall is possible with too much slack. Continue straight up past one more bolt on easy ground to to bolt anchor at top small ledge.
content.location: The route is located around the corner and slightly left of Dog Gone It. There is another short three bolt face (Girl's Best Friend) just six feet to the left of this route and they share the same double bolt anchors.

content.description: A long low angled dihedral. Pitch one start in low angled right facing dihedral climb straight up to tree 70 feet. Belay at tree or double bolts out on face; or continue up dihedral to its end to a two bolt belay at top of dihedral. Hard to see the double bolts until you are right on top of them. Rappel once with a 70 meter rope or make two rappels with a 60 meter rope down face. Possible to scramble off if preferred.
content.protection: Double set of cams from .5-4". It is possible to use a 5" and 6" cam if desired but the groud is easier when the crack reaches that size. Med to large stoppers.
content.location: An obvious right facing dihedral between two bolted slab climbs at the base of the Girlie Man Area.

content.description: This is one of the longer slab climbs in the area. The crux is around the first bolt and the climbing continues far past that. It is run out on easier ground. Start on low angle face climbing up to a vertical rail and clip the first bolt. Continue straight up for approximately 15 feet to second bolt then straight up to a two bolt anchor; belay here or continue on past one more single bolt heading towards the top of the low angle dihedral to the climbers left. There are two bolts on the top of the dihedral. They are hard to see until you are right on top of them. It can be done in one long pitch. A 70 meter rope will let you descend with a single rappel or rappel with a 60 meter rope twice and the middle belay. Nice route to teach multi pitch to a beginning climber. Fun run out slab route. It is possible to scramble off but it will be a long scramble.
content.location: This route is on the right side of the long low angled slab. There is a large low angled dihedral to the left of the route with a tree growing out of the crack about half of the way of the route.

content.description: This route is kinda contrived. For some, it might be a boulder problem, for others it might be a waste of time. At the time, it looked worth checking out and it ended up being okay. Ive only climbed it once and might not climb it again. But its there and worth a try if you cant think of anything else you want to do. It was gloomy and rainy all day that day and our other option besides climbing would have been to sit on our asses and watch Its Always Sunny in Philadelphia.
content.protection: A Long rabbit runner sling that you can lasso around the pinnacle before traversing left to the crack. Camalots between #1-4
content.location: On the opposite hillside of the canyon in which Girlie Man is located. If youre hiking up canyon this route is on the left. Girlie man on the right. Look for the elephant ear looking feature.

content.description: This route is a three bolt low angled slab climb located the farthest left of the wall. Climb straight up past three bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location: This route is located the farthest left on the wall at the Girlie Man area.

The route is located up and right of large slab. Short 4th class scramble. It is North facing and hard to see until you are under it. There is a prominent finger crack 5 feet to the left of it on the same face.

content.description: This is a short but wandering slab line. Start to the left of a low scoop climbing straight up to first bolt. Traverse right over scoop clipping second bolt. Continue up past thin horizontal crack past two more bolts in low angle trough up to a two bolt anchor.
content.location: This is perhaps the most easily seen route encountered in the Girlie Man Area.

content.description: Back in 06/07 we were romping around the McDowells constantly. We were climbing everything we could get our hands on. We know there were tons of climbers to test their skills in the area far before we ever graced this planet. We climbed the classics and climbed other lines that just looked worth a try..or several. On one full moon night we spent hours trying this thin slab boulder problem just to the right of the outstanding handcrack. After countless falls my good friend craig finally pulled over the top. By that point I was no longer spotting and instead watching his determination and drive play out to be one of his greatest climbing highlights. First ascent or not it made for some great memories. If anyone has any other info please post. Since this is still a project for me I had no idea what to rate it, get on it and tell me what you think.
content.location: Just right of the awesome handcrack

content.description: This is a mixed area with a few slab and a few traditional crack routes. The rock is typical granite found throughout the McDowell Mountain park.
